comments.text:
Comparing including same sex relationships in Tomodachi life, to disabled 
people.. I don't see anyone throwing fits, except for the people being 
angry about people pointing out some weird flaws. I wouldn't mind the 
wheelchair thing either but that's something completely random.

The fact is, it wouldn't be so hard for them to not have to make everyone 
straight. Also, they already have romance and relationships in this game, 
and with that follows sexuality, naturally. Like in Sims, it just happens. 
It's not a big deal, they wouldn't have to include anything, they'd only 
have to have the miis be able to fall in love with everyone. That's why 
people are a bit annoyed. It's a very simple thing to do. They would almost 
have to do nothing. They have programmed them to be straight. That's more 
work than just let shit happen.

Personally I don't mind either way, I would prefer to have it be slightly 
more realistic in that one aspect though. And I don't see any reason for 
that to be annoying so many people. What is it with people getting mad 
about constructive criticism or personal preference?

I see lots of people complaining about tons of other games. No one gives a 
crap. But as soon as it involves gay people, it's because gay people are 
crazy  and narcissistic. I'm not even gay myself, but relax.
comments.author: OurWorldAhead

comments.author: TS Prism

comments.text:
+HammettSHREDZ True, but by adding the gay characters you'd be pushing

It was probably just easier for them to skip the controversy and just not

comments.author: Da Cawtz

comments.text:
+Da Cawtz Perhaps my understanding of "strawman" argument was a bit 
misconstrued. 

However, it is not right to exclude homosexual relationships when this game 
features a dating mechanic. Including homosexual relationships isn't 
pandering or homogenizing or unnecessary like you seem to think it is with 
your (rather flawed) Call of Duty comparison, it's basic sense. Call of 
Duty's target demographic is anyone who's into guns and shooting, not 
"males". Just like Tomodachi Life's demographic is anyone who's into quirky 
life sims, not specifically heterosexuals. Or, rather, ideally, it *should* 
be. 

Let's drop whether the exclusion of other facets of life is the same as 
this. Instead, let's imagine the reality of game development. 

How easy would it be to include male on male or female on female pairings? 
Or even bisexual relationships? Pretty goddamn simple. It's purely text and 
visual dressing, but it's enough to get the job done. You've just pleased a 
considerable amount of your demographic with VERY little effort, minority 
or not. 

Now, how easy would it be to include wheelchair Mii's? That requires extra 
animations for every activity/occurrence in the game, which is a lot. It 
essentially doubles the amount of animations. That's a lot of work for the 
(likely) even fewer in wheelchairs that would pick this game up. 

What about mental disabilities? Amputees? You see where I'm going with 
this? 

It's not the same. Them excluding homosexual/bisexual relations in a game 
that's advertising itself as a life sim that features dating simply isn't 
acceptable in this age.
comments.author: HammettSHREDZ

comments.text:
+HammettSHREDZ It is right to exclude homosexual relationships, because it 
is the vast minority, not the target demographic. Why does call of duty 
have guns and shooting instead of fairies and magic, it excludes females!

A hypothetical comparison is not a strawman argument. A strawman argument 
is purposely MISREPRESENTING the argument. He isn't saying you're claiming 
the disabled/enabled discrimination.

A strawman would be if he were saying you wanted to remove all the straight 
characters and make it exclusively gay, which is clearly not your 
intention, he just states it that way because it's easier to refute.
comments.author: Da Cawtz

comments.text:
Yes. Because they already have an option for straight relationships. To 
then exclude homosexual relationships isn't right, especially in this day 
and age. It's partially a dating sim. 

Disabled/Enabled (whatever you wanna call the opposite) isn't the same as 
Hetero/Homo in this case if any case. It's such a strawman argument. You're 
comparing somebody's sexual preference to whether or not they're physically 
or mentally disabled.
comments.author: HammettSHREDZ

comments.text:
+HammettSHREDZ So because it is an "entire sexuality", it is more 
important? Devs shouldn't have to waste their time accommodating to a 
minority of gamers.

comments.text:
+Luis Manuel Birth YEAR is actually optional, and if you don't set one, you 
can choose whether the Mii's a child or adult. Their birth year is used for 
a few minor features ingame, though, and ones without a birth year are 
incompatible with those features. (This isn't at ALL a big deal, however, 
so there's no real obligation to put a birth year if you really don't want 
to.)

Some people might not buy it if that feature is added. Especially if it's 
highlighted specifically. I think that's a possible action that could

The feature wasn't in the game. They don't have to add it to the game. 
There are other Life Simulators out there. Why haven't they been attacked 
and "forced" to add a homosexual relationship option in the game?

They shouldn't have apologized. I explained this in my video if you'd like 
to give it a watch. My video probably sounds better than this. Nintendo did 
nothing wrong. They often don't acknowledge a lot of things. Why was this 
acknowledged? It would've gone away after a while. If you don't want the 
game, don't buy it. Simple as that. People made Nintendo look like the 
villain in the situation when they should've been looking at themselves. If 
I feel that a feature has been left out of a game or just not thought of 
and I complain to Nintendo about it, they won't add it. What makes this 
situation any different? Oh it's because they're gay. Sexual orientation 
automatically trumps over everything, huh? I think they're idiots if they 
won't buy the game for this. I'm straight. What if there were no 
relationships at all? I wouldn't care. Maybe they should do that. Either 
way, people will find something to complain and in some cases, their 
whining will pay off.

top_comment.text:
When thinking about the whole "gay marriage" fiasco, I am pretty much 
neutral. I can understand both sides. I can understand that homosexuals are 
pissed, because they can't play the game the way they want and seeing their 
look-alike being in a heterosexual relationship might feel awkward or 
irritating. On the other hand due to the random nature of the game the 
implementation of this would be pretty hard, too. Are you going to 
implement set probabilities for Miis being gay? But what about the exact 
percentages then? Setting them as 50:50 wouldn't even closely resemble 
reality, but setting them to be realistic (aka homosexuals being a 
minority) might feel discriminating against them. The only sensible thing I 
can think of is to have the player set the probabilities on his own in some 
kind of options menu.﻿

captions.text: Before actually playing Tomodachi Life, I had no idea what to think. I knew it was a life sim

game, a genre that's never been able to hold
my interest, and that it seemed absolutely

weird and wacky. The other problem was that
it starred the Miis, and the avatars have

never really done that much for me. It was
always cool to see the creativity people had

when making them, but they were always just
that: avatars. No personality of their own;

just a way to make players feel like they're
in the game. But with Tomodachi Life, that

all changed. For the first time, I actually
cared about the Miis. And at the very least,

that's one heck of an accomplishment.
Tomodachi Life begins with you creating or

importing a Mii of yourself. Soon you're introduced
to your own island which you can name, and

it's up to you to populate it. As you do,
you'll see the Miis interact and more shops

and activities will become available as you
play. While this does sound similar to Animal

Crossing, it's different in just how much
customization can be done. Every single Mii

has to be given a full name and a birthday.
This will determine their age and exactly

what kind of relationships can be forged while
on the island.

But it goes a step further in that every Mii
also has a voice, one that you can change

to match how you think they sound. They can
be as throaty or as high pitched as you want.

I was even able to make Andre into an extremely
fast talker. Once the voice is set, the Mii

can be given a personality. Answering a quick
survey will give the Mii its personality and

will determine just how well he or she gets
along with the other residents. It really

does give the player an amazing amount of
control. You can fill your island with your

friends and family, celebrities, historical
figures, or, in my case, video game characters.

You can even mix and match if you want. You
don't have to make all of these Miis yourself

though. Simply scan a QR code containing the
Mii, and it will pop up into your game. However,

this may limit what you can change about their
appearance and name. It's why I have a Japanese

Mario.
Once you've created your Mii, it moves into

the island's apartment complex. It starts
off small but as you add more Miis to your

island, it will grow bigger to accommodate.
At this point, you're free to do whatever

you want though the main goal is to see your
island grow and add new features. Each location

has a specific prerequisite for how it opens,
but simply interacting with the Miis will

eventually open them up. There's a grocery
store with a daily rotating menu though anything

you buy once can be bought again on another
day. The same idea applies to clothing and

even apartment themes. Every Mii has their
own tastes and buying these items could increase

the Mii's happiness. The more they like it,
the more their happiness will rise and the

more money they'll give you.
You can then use this money to buy even more

items. Of course you can also earn money by
getting donations from Miis at the fountain

or by selling the gifts that they give you
at the pawn shop. Money never really becomes

a problem as there's always something you
can do with the Miis. They'll either want

to meet a fellow Mii and hope a new friendship
is forged, want to play a game where you can

earn new items, or have problems that you
can solve. Each one will reward you with happiness

for the Mii, money, or new items.
While Animal Crossing focuses on you, Tomodachi

Life is all about the Miis. As they live on
the island together they'll develop relationships.

Some will become friends and couples can even
be made. The Miis will even have bad days

where they'll fight amongst themselves. But
one of the key features that Nintendo has

advertised is that Miis can become romantically
involved and even have babies. Unfortunately,

I was unable to experience that feature before
review. That being said, even experiencing

the Miis' daily lives without romance is surprisingly
fun. You never quite know what their reactions

will be and sometimes it just gets so weird
that you can't help but laugh.

The feature that I found myself constantly
revisiting though was the Concert Hall. One

of the items you can give the Miis when they
reach a new happiness level is a song. It

can be in one of eight genres and all come
with their own lyrics. It was incredibly amusing

to take these genres and write in the lyrics
to existing songs. In that way, it becomes

like the Vocaloid games and while not all
of them work, they never stopped being entertaining

for me. Groups can even be formed to really
spice up the performances.

And that's really the key to enjoying Tomodachi
Life. It's all about experimentation to see

what each of them like and don't like. You
can be as weird or as normal as you feel,

but the game has an innate sense of the weird.
This is a game where you can spy on the dreams

of your residents and then pull items from
those dreams. This is a game where you can

dress Miis in whatever crazy outfit you want.
And it's all done according to your schedule.

There's no need to return to the game every
day. The Miis won't berate you for not visiting.

It truly makes the game perfect for just winding
down and playing at my own pace even if I

don't do it for weeks at a time.
Players can even use Streetpass to visit each

other's islands or trade goods. Spotpass will
eventually give out special items as well.

Unfortunately, I was also unable to check
out either of these features. But the core

game is so charming on its own that I feel
that Streetpass is simply a way to get more

out of it.
The presentation fits the game perfectly.

This isn't a graphical powerhouse or anything,
but it does provide a sense that the Miis

are living here. And keeping the graphics
simple works well with the style of the Miis

though the few times realistic pictures and
models appear, they are used to humorous effect.

The same could be said of the music. They're
simple, but they fit the world. It keeps things

at a relaxed pace at all times. And each of
the eight genres for the Concert Hall is stuck

in my head, especially the Pop song and the
Ballad.

Tomodachi Life is a great addition to the
life sim genre. While you could attach some

of its ideas to The Sims or Animal Crossing,
it really does feel like its own thing. Considering

how little I typically care about these types
of games, I'm surprised how much I really

enjoyed it. In fact, I liked it a lot. And
if you're a fan of the genre or even just

curious, it's well worth trying out. Thanks
for watching and be sure to stay tuned to

GameXplain for more on Tomodachi Life and
other things gaming.
